summary:
Subject: Comprehensive Digest on ProPM Roles & Responsibilities  

Dear Team,  

Below is a detailed summary of the ProPM Roles & Responsibilities Confluence page. This digest includes all visual and textual content, providing a thorough overview of processes, workflows, roles, and responsibilities.  

Overview:  
The ProPM Roles & Responsibilities page outlines the processes, workflows, and roles involved in project, program, and portfolio management within the ProPM framework. It includes detailed diagrams, resource allocation tables, and RACI matrices to clarify responsibilities and provide guidance for project execution and governance.  

Key Content:  

• IMAGE 1: Process Flow Diagram for Project, Program, and Portfolio Management  
 • Represents the relationship between demand management, portfolio management, and project/program management.  
 • Key sections include "Portfolio Management," "Demand Management," and "Project/Program Management," with subsections such as "Resource Management," "Governance," and "Financial Management."  
 • Highlights the flow of ideas from proposal to execution, with roles such as "Idea Proposer," "Project Advocate," and "Project Manager."  
 • Descriptions include:  
   • Demand Management: Receiving, evaluating, and deciding on project requests.  
   • Portfolio Management: Monthly reassessment and optimization of the portfolio.  
   • Resource Management: Allocating resources based on capacity and priority.  
   • Project/Program Management: Managing project progress, risks, financials, and quality.  
 • Visual elements include loops, arrows, and color-coded sections (blue for portfolio management, teal for demand management, gold for project/program management).  

• IMAGE 2: Roles & Responsibilities Table with RACI Assignments  
 • A table outlining roles and responsibilities for managing engineering and business unit projects.  
 • Columns include roles such as Portfolio Manager, Eng Mgmt Team, Resource Manager, Finance Partner, Eng Project Manager (TPL), BU Project Manager, BU Portfolio Team, and BU Advocate.  
 • Tasks include adding financial data, converting ideas to projects, entering new ideas/projects, identifying resource demands, maintaining department structure, and updating financial forecasts.  
 • RACI assignments:  
   • "R" (Responsible): Assigned to roles directly accountable for completing tasks.  
   • "S" (Supports): Assigned to roles providing assistance.  
   • "I" (Inform): Assigned to roles needing updates.  
 • Key annotations:  
   • Resource Manager and TPL roles may overlap.  
   • Roles span both engineering and business unit projects.  

• IMAGE 3: Resource Allocation Table Screenshot  
 • A table embedded in an email, detailing resource allocations for ProPM investments.  
 • Columns include Resource Name, Resource ID, Investment Name, Investment ID, Investment Type, Project Manager/Advocate, Allocated By, Allocation Start/Finish Dates, Default % Allocation, and Portfolio OBS.  
 • Example data:  
   • Resource: Garrison, Jaime; Investment: NPI Idea X; Allocation: 25% from Nov 13, 2020, to Nov 14, 2024.  
   • Resource: Cunningham, Mary; Investment: Aftermarket Project Y; Allocation: 40% from Mar 1, 2024, to Apr 1, 2024.  
 • Email context: Notification sent to resource managers when team members are allocated to projects by others.  

• IMAGE 4: Flowchart for Initiating a New ProPM Project  
 • A sequential flowchart outlining steps to initiate and plan a new ProPM project.  
 • Steps include:  
   • Project kickoff meeting.  
   • High-level planning and estimation with technical leads.  
   • Determining start/end dates, effort, and required competencies.  
   • Committing resource names.  
 • All steps culminate in the creation of a "New ProPM Project."  

For Technical Teams:  
• Processes and workflows:  
 • Demand management, portfolio management, and project/program management processes.  
 • Resource allocation adjustments and capacity reviews.  
 • Steps for initiating and planning new projects.  
• RACI assignments:  
 • Detailed roles and responsibilities for tasks in engineering and business unit projects.  
• System/tool information:  
 • Resource allocation table provides structured data for tracking resources and investments.  
• Action items:  
 • Ensure alignment of resource allocations with project requirements.  
 • Follow the outlined steps for project initiation and planning.  

For Managers & Stakeholders:  
• Business relevance:  
 • Clear delineation of roles and responsibilities ensures accountability and efficiency.  
 • Resource allocation transparency supports better decision-making.  
• Resource implications:  
 • Resource Managers play a critical role in balancing capacity and demand.  
 • Notifications improve communication regarding resource assignments.  
• Governance and decision points:  
 • Portfolio Managers lead planning and governance processes.  
 • CIP Governance Committee reviews and approves project proposals.  

This comprehensive summary captures all content from the ProPM Roles & Responsibilities page, ensuring no detail is overlooked. Please review and share any feedback or questions.  

Best regards,  
CIP Weekly Digest
